newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks seen mixed to sliding, peso firmer.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks seen mixed to sliding, peso firmer.

text.p: Dealers saw stocks opening mixed to down on Wednesday on continuing month-end pressures on money market liquidity and the peso, the latter triggered by disappointing trade figures.
"The market will be soft for a couple of days yet, until month-end pressures ease," a desk trader said.
Technical analysts situated support for the IPC index at 3,940 points, compared to Tuesday's close of 3,960.86.
Traders expected the peso to open firmer as the U.S. 30-year Treasury bond partially recovered from Tuesday's falls, up 4/32 to yield 7.02 percent in early trading.
Dealers forecast a trading range of 7.8900/7.9100 per dollar for the 48-hour peso. Pre-open bids stood at 7.8900/7.9010 per dollar, compared to Tuesday's close of 7.8960/7.9000.

Overnight rates on Cetes were seen down at the open from Tuesday's high close of 18.50 percent. Nonetheless, dealers said trading rates could rise during the session following increases in primary rates on Tuesday night.
Banco de Mexico assigned bellwether 28-day Cetes rates at 18.31 percent at Tuesday night's primary auction, an increase of 24 basis points since last week.
This compares with a rise of 12 basis points predicted in a Reuters survey conducted before the auction took place.
Mexico reported a trade surplus of $109 million for the month of April, far less than the market expected.
